title: 112_s1417
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fuel Cell Industrial Vehicle Jobs Act of 2011" and includes modifications to the credit for qualified fuel cell motor vehicles. The "Fuel Cell Industrial Vehicle Jobs Act of 2011" amends the credit amounts for motor vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating of not more than 8,500 pounds under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit amounts are $4,000 for vehicles described in subsection (b)(4)(A) and $8,000 for vehicles described in subsection (h)(1). The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes special rules for certain off-highway vehicles, defining "motor vehicle" to include vehicles primarily used for commercial or industrial purposes, excluding vehicles operated on rails or for recreational purposes. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes special rules for certain off-highway vehicles, defining "motor vehicle" to include vehicles primarily used for commercial or industrial purposes, excluding vehicles operated on rails or for recreational purposes. Additionally, for vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating not exceeding 8,500 pounds, the tax credit amount determined under paragraph (1) is increased by $1,500 if the fuel cell system achieves an electricity generation efficiency of at least 40 percent based on the lower heating value of the fuel. For vehicles with a weight rating over 8,500 pounds, the tax credit amount increases by $2,000 for an electricity generation efficiency of 40-50% and $4,000 for over 50% efficiency. Certain standards do not apply to these vehicles. The tax credit for vehicles with a weight rating over 8,500 pounds increases based on electricity generation efficiency. Certain standards do not apply to these vehicles. The credit is only available for vehicles placed in service after December 31, 2010. The amendments made by this section apply to vehicles placed in service after that date in taxable years ending after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. ENERGY CREDIT FOR FUEL CELL MOTIVE PROPERTY. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection for a tax credit on new qualified fuel cell motive property. The credit amount is based on the capacity of the property, with varying rates for different capacity ranges. The tax credit for new qualified fuel cell motive property is based on capacity, with a rate of $50 for each additional 0.5 kilowatt above 15.0 kilowatts. The credit amount is capped at $12,700 per property placed in service during the taxable year. The term 'new qualified fuel cell motive property' refers to qualified fuel cell property manufactured for use in powering qualified motive property. The tax credit for new qualified fuel cell motive property is based on capacity, with a rate of $50 for each additional 0.5 kilowatt above 15.0 kilowatts, capped at $12,700 per property placed in service during the taxable year. Qualified motive property is defined as property manufactured primarily for commercial or industrial purposes, not on public streets or for recreational use. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include expanding the subsections eligible for the tax credit. The amendments made by this section define a fuel cell power plant as an integrated system converting fuel into electricity using electrochemical means. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2010.
